did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, legal papers, notes, and other materials documenting Weinberger's career as a lawyer who specialized in civil liberties cases and, later in his career, copyright law. The one hundred and sixteen (116) case files include legal briefs, writs, and memoranda prepared by Weinberger and his staff, and similar material prepared by opposing attorneys. Correspondence files include letters with clients and individuals interested in a specific case. Weinberger's clients included: Alexander Berkman, Grover Cleveland Bergdoll, Emma Goldman, and Eugene O'Neill. The papers also include a small number of Weinberg's short stories and plays and correspondence with his nephew, Warren Weinberger.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Harold M. Wayne, 1944; Beatrice Mitherz, 2000; and Warren J. Weinberger, 2000.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown, though much of the material in this collection is likely in the public domain. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Harry Weinberger Papers (MS 553). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Harry Weinberger was born in New York City in 1888. He attended New York University and was admitted to the bar in 1908. A staunch believer in civil liberties, Weinberger defended many aliens, immigrants, anarchists, and other radicals, including Emma Goldman and Alexander Berkman, whom he believed had been deprived of their rights. He also developed an expertise in copyright law, representing many writers, including Eugene O'Neill. Weinberger died in 1944.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: For additional Weinberger papers see the following collections in the Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library: Madeleine Elise (Reynier) Boyd; Louis Bromfield; James Hagan; Eugene O'Neill; Channing Pollock.
Papers related to Madame Rosika Schwimmer's suit against Upton Sinclair and William Fox are in the Schwimmer-Lloyd Collection, New York Public Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of correspondence, legal papers, notes, and other materials documenting Weinberger's career as a lawyer who specialized in civil liberties cases and, later in his career, copyright law. The one hundred and sixteen (116) case files include legal briefs, writs, and memoranda prepared by Weinberger and his staff, and similar material prepared by opposing attorneys. Correspondence files include letters with clients and individuals interested in a specific case. Weinberger's clients included: Alexander Berkman, Grover Cleveland Bergdoll, Emma Goldman, and Eugene O'Neill. The papers also include a small number of Weinberg's short stories and plays and correspondence with his nephew, Warren Weinberger.

The Harry Weinberger Papers cover Weinberger's professional career from around 1915 until the early 1940s. In that time, Weinberger handled many types of cases, but he took a special interest in people whom he believed had been deprived of their civil liberties. As a result, Weinberger defended many aliens, immigrants, anarchists, and radicals. Two of Weinberger's most celebrated clients were the anarchists Emma Goldman and Alexander Berkman. Another client of Weinberger was the wealthy draft dodger, Grover Cleveland Bergdoll. Most of Weinberger's clients were, however, neither famous nor wealthy. Many were referred to Weinberger by service agencies like the American Civil Liberties Union, the League for Amnesty of Political Prisoners, and the Worker's Defense Fund.

In the later part of his career, Weinberger became an expert in copyright law, representing many writers, including Eugene O'Neill, in copyright and plagiarism suits. Weinberger corresponded with many prominent figures in connection with his legal work. His correspondents include Roger N. Baldwin, William A. Black, Alice Stone Blackwell, Harry M. Daugherty, Albert DeSilver, Elizabeth G. Flynn, Agnes Inglis, Daniel Kiefer, Robert M. LaFollette, Alvaro Obregon, Elmer Rice, Upton Sinclair, Lincoln Steffans, Norman Thomas, Frank P. Walsh, Thomas E. Watson and Stephen S. Wise.

The papers provide information on United States policies toward aliens, anarchists, and radicals in America during and after the first World War. The papers also contain material on United States immigration and deportation policies and important materials on Emma Goldman, Alexander Berkman, Ricardo Flores Magon, and Tom Mooney. There is, however, very little personal material on Weinberger in the papers. Biographical information can be found in Weinberger's "A Rebel's Interrupted Autobiography" published in the American Journal of Economics and Sociology in 1 October 1942.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The main accession is arranged in alphabetical order according to name of client. Two additions are arranged alphabetically by type of material.

odd.head: Index of Correspondents
odd.p: The following index is designed as an aid in finding significant letters and letters of prominent persons in this collection. Because the correspondence in the papers is grouped into more than one hundred sections, a correspondent may have letters filed in more than one section. Each of the selected correspondents is listed separately, followed by the name of the section or sections in which letters by that correspondent may be found. For example, the listing of Louis D. Brandeis appears as follows:

list.head: Brandeis, Louis D.

odd.p: This means that correspondence with Brandeis may be found in three sections: Jacob Abrams, The God of Vengeance , and Emma Goldman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters and legal papers concerning New York vs. Samuel Abels , 1917. Abels was arrested, tried, and convicted for desecration of the flag. Weinberger appealed the conviction to the New York Supreme Court, alleging there was no violation of law, merely an expression of opinion. The lower court ruling was affirmed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, notes, and miscellaneous papers concerning the cases: United States vs. Jacob Abrams et al. , United States vs. Gabriel Prober et al. , and Jacob Abrams et al. vs. United States , 1918-1921.

Jacob Abrams, Hyman Lachowsky, Samuel Lipman, Gabriel Prober, Hyman Rosansky, Jacob Schwartz, and Mollie Steimer were admitted anarchists charged with violating the wartime Espionage Act. The defendents had distributed pamphlets denouncing American intervention in Russia in 1918 as contrary to the best interests of the Russian people. Prober, Schwartz, and Rosansky were dropped from the case, leaving the "Four Russians - Jacob Abrams, Hyman Lachowsky, Samuel Lipman, and Mollie Steimer. Weinberger was attorney for the accused, and after their conviction in 1918, he unsuccessfully sought to obtain executive clemency. The "Four Russians" were deported to the USSR in 1923. Interest in this case was widespread, due in large part to Weinberger's efforts in publicizing the impact of the trial and the convictions on the civil liberties of the individual. This section includes letters from many prominent Americans expressing their opinions on this case.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The League was interested in cases concerning civil liberties and rights in wartime. This section contains notes and opinions by Weinberger, council for the League, on the cases of Loewe DeBoer, George L. Glison, Henry Jager, and Joseph Sadokierski. More material on these four cases is filed separately under the individual names.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of correspondence. Weinberger arranged bond for actor Andreyeff who was being held for deportation. Andreyeff was deported to Russia in 1921.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, notes, and miscellaneous concerning United States vs. George Andreytchine , 1919-1923. Weinberger acted as attorney for Andreytchine, a member of the International Workers of the World (I. W. W.), and obtained his release on $10,000 bail. Andreytchine disappeared and the bail was forfeited in 1922.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, notes, and miscellaneous papers concerning New York vs. Harry Aurin , 1917. Weinberger defended Aurin who was charged with disorderly conduct and the distribution of illegal handbills. The handbills contained excerpts from the Declaration of Independence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, notes, clippings, and miscellaneous papers concerning United States vs. W. B. Bales , 1917 (United States District Court, New York), and United States vs. W. B. Bales , 1918 (United States Supreme Court). William B. Bales was arrested on a charge of failing to register for the draft and released on bail. The case was dismissed and Bales was ordered to perform non-combatant duty. The bail money was ordered returned less 1% for clerk's fees. Weinberger successfully appealed to the United States Supreme Court on the grounds that the deduction was unconstitutional.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: See: U.S. Department of Justice, box 4, folder 3

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters and miscellaneous papers. Weinberger was attorney for author Barnes in a dispute with the Liveright Publishing Corporation over the terms of her contract and the rights to the book Nightwood .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, clippings, and miscellaneous papers concerning United States vs. Rose Baron , 1919-1920. Baron, an alien, was charged with being a communist and held for deportation. Weinberger secured her release because of the illegal procedure of her arrest, lack of evidence that she was a communist, and Secretary of Labor Wilson's decision that membership in the Communist Party was not grounds for deportation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, and miscellaneous papers concerning United States vs. Morris Becker , 1918-1920. While serving a term in the United States Penitentiary in Atlanta, Becker refused to register for the draft. Upon his release he was re-arrested by the Department of Justice and held for deportation by the Department of Labor as an anarchist. Weinberger got the Selective Service violation dismissed and Becker was deported to Russia with Emma Goldman and Alexander Berkman in December 1919.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, notes, clippings, and miscellaneous papers. Weinberger's association with Grover Cleveland Bergdoll spans more than twenty years. Bergdoll, World War One's most infamous draft dodger, was court-martialed in 1920 and sentenced to five years confinement. Weinberger served as his attorney. In May of 1920, Bergdoll escaped and fled to Germany where he married and raised a family.

In 1939, Bergdoll voluntarily returned to the United States. He was taken into custody by military authorities and was tried and convicted for escape and desertion. Weinberger again served as attorney. Weinberger also aided Bergdoll in other matters. He arranged the return of large amounts of Bergdoll's property that had been seized by the Alien Property Custodian. He also lobbied against a bill sponsored by Representative Forest A. Harness that would have prevented Bergdoll's return to the United States.

Relations were not always cordial between Weinberger and his client. Conflict over Weinberger's dealings with the Alien Property Custodian prompted Bergdoll to discharge Weinberger in 1939. Weinberger brought suit against Bergdoll in 1940 to collect fees he claimed were due him.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The legal papers, notes, clippings, and miscellaneous papers are arranged into several general sections as follows: A) Draft/ first court-martial, B) New habeas corpus, C) Second court-martial/ appeal, D) Alien property, E) Harness bill, F) Harry Weinberger vs. Bergdolls, and G) Newspaper and magazine clippings.
These seven sections contain overlapping and related materials and are not rigid, separate files.
A) Draft/ first court-martial: This section contains material on Bergdoll's arrest for desertion, the habeas corpus proceeding, and the 1920 court-martial.

B) New habeas corpus: Upon his voluntary return to the United States in 1939, Bergdoll was held by military authorities. New habeas corpus proceedings were begun in 1939. These papers concern the new habeas corpus, the appeals to the Circuit Court, and, after denial there, to the Supreme Court. The petition for the writ of certiorari was prepared by Weinberger though he was no longer attorney in the case. Also filed with these papers are some documents relating to the original habeas corpus proceedings.
C) Second court-martial/ appeal: This section contains materials used in Bergdoll's second court-martial.
D) Alien property: This material concerns Weinberger's attempts to recover property of the Bergdoll family confiscated by the Alien Property Custodian.

E) Harness bill: This section contains miscellaneous pamphlets, notes, and statements relating to Weinberger's activities in opposition to a bill introduced by Representative Forest A. Harness that sought to exclude from the United States persons convicted of desertion from the military while the United States is at war.

F) Harry Weinberger vs. Bergdolls : In 1940, Weinberger brought suit against Grover Cleveland Bergdoll and his wife in an attempt to collect money due him as fees for his services as attorney. The case was settled out of court. Included in this section are early agreements and retainers.

G) Newspaper and magazine clippings: This section contains clippings relating to Bergdoll's first arrest and court-martial, his flight to Germany, and his subsequent return to the United States and trial. Most of the clippings date from 1939.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, and miscellaneous papers concerning United States vs. Paul Bosco , 1919-1921. Bosco was convicted for distributing a pamphlet entitled "The Price We Pay" and sentenced to two years in the Atlanta Penitentiary. Upon his release, Bosco was held for deportation as an anarchist. Sponsored by the Workers' Defense Union and the American Civil Liberties Union, Weinberger requested a reopening of the case on the basis of additional evidence. The arrest and deportation warrants were eventually cancelled. This case aroused widespread discussion of the rights of aliens. Included in these papers are Weinberger's replies to the attack on him by the American Legion and to Congressman Albert Johnson's speech "Alien Anarchist Set Free."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, and miscellaneous papers concerning United States vs. Edka Bottvinick , 1920. Bottvinick was charged with being an anarchist and a member of the Communist Party, and held for deportation. Weinberger had the warrant of deportation cancelled because of lack of evidence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters and miscellaneous papers. Weinberger was retained by the Italian Workers' Defense League to represent Buzzi, a conscientious objector sentenced to fifteen years of hard labor (later commuted to four) for disobeying an order. Weinberger obtained amnesty for Buzzi, after he had served two years three months of his sentence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters and miscellaneous papers concerning New York vs. Tomaso Campeo , 1919. Weinberger acted as attorney for Tomaso Campeo, charged with carrying a revolver.

scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, notes, and miscellaneous papers. Weinberger served as the legal advisor and attorney for the Cape Playhouse and the Cape Playhouse Cinema, Dennis, Cape Cod, Massachusetts. Weinberger also served as personal attorney for owner Raymond Moore.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, notes, and miscellaneous papers concerning Gloria Carruthers vs. Loew's Inc. , 1938-1940. Weinberger served as attorney for Gloria Carruthers, an entertainer and mentalist known professionally as Zuleika. Carruthers brought charges against Loew's Inc. for defamation of character and loss of income caused by the presentation of a character, Zuleika, as a phony and drunk seeress in the MGM motion picture Idiot's Delight . She was awarded $1000 damages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters and legal papers concerning United States vs. Lena Chenenky , 1920-1922. Lena Chenenky was charged with being an anarchist and a member of the Communist Party and held for deportation. Weinberger succeeded in having the warrant for deportation cancelled due to a lack of evidence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, notes, clippings, and miscellaneous papers concerning Sheldon Cheney vs. Simon and Schuster Inc. , 1936-1937. In 1929, Cheney submitted to Simon and Schuster a plan for an anthology of plays which they rejected. In 1935, Simon and Schuster published a drama anthology which Cheney claimed followed his plan. Weinberger brought suit against Simon and Schuster. The final decision in the case was against Cheney.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters and notes concerning United States vs. Andrea Ciafalo , 1919. Andrea Ciafalo, an alien, was indicted for failure to register for the draft. Weinberger succeeded in having the indictment dismissed. Ciafalo was then charged with criminal anarchy and the government began deportation proceedings. When Ciafalo failed to appear for examination at Ellis Island, Weinberger resigned as his attorney.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters and legal papers concerning New York vs. Maurice Cohen , 1917. Cohen was charged with disturbing the peace by distributing leaflets advertising a mass meeting against conscription. Weinberger served as attorney.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, notes, and miscellaneous concerning College Entrance Book Co. vs. McGraw-Hill Book Co. and Augustus H. Smith , 1938-1940. Weinberger, attorney for the plaintiff, charged that Augustus H. Smith's Economics, An Introduction to Fundamental Problems , published by McGraw-Hill, reproduced verbatim many parts of Richard Feier's An Introduction to the Elements of Economic Problems , published and copyright by the College Entrance Book Co. A compromise was reached before the case came to trial.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, notes, clippings, and miscellaneous papers concerning Delores L. Collins vs. Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer , 1932-1940. Weinberger was attorney for Delores Lacy Collins (Henderson), widow of test pilot James H. Collins. Mrs. Henderson brought suit against MGM on a charge of infringement of the copyright of the book Test Pilot , written by her late husband. She also charged unfair competition in using the title of the book as the title of a photoplay. The case was tried and dismissed. Weinberger appealled and won a decision awarding the plaintiff monetary compensation.

scopecontent.p: The papers consist of correspondence concerning New York vs. Leon Cooper , 1917. Cooper was in an auto accident and seriously injured a boy. He retained Weinberger to represent him in the above named action.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, notes, clippings, and miscellaneous papers. Weinberger served as attorney and legal advisor for radio entertainer and singer Crumit. Weinberger represented Crumit in a suit brought by A. F. Ryan who charged Crumit with using some words from her song "Her Old Spanish Shawl" to the tune of Crumit's composition "A Gay Caballero." Weinberger also served as attorney for Crumit in a contract dispute with actor A. E. Matthews. Weinberger advised Crumit on tax matters and on Crumit's attempts to produce a musical play entitled "Great Lady."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of legal papers concerning New York vs. Loewe DeBoer, 1917. DeBoer was charged with refusal to enlist and pacifist utterances. He was placed in the Observation Ward of Bellevue Hospital. Weinberger served as attorney.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, notes, and miscellaneous papers concerning New York vs. Alexander Derkach, Ivan Novikoff, and Leon Bobkin , 1918. Derkach, Novikoff, and Bobkin were charged with criminal anarchy for printing and distributing a pamphlet "Kolokol" (The Bell), which advocated overthrow of the United States Government. Weinberger succeeded in having the case dismissed because the state could not prove that the defendents believed in or taught the ideas advocated in the pamphlet.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, and notes. Dorfman, an alien, was charged with prostitution and held for deportation. Weinberger failed in one attempt to have the warrant cancelled, but eventually the commissioner of immigration of New York cancelled the warrant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters and legal papers concerning New York vs. Harold Eckardt , 1916. Eckardt was sentenced to six months in jail for trespassing on a freight train. Weinberger succeeded in having the sentence reduced to three months.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, notes, clippings, and miscellaneous papers concerning New York vs. Hagbard Ekerold , 1909-1914. Ekerold refused to let his son be vaccinated. When the boy was denied admittance to school, Ekerold was charged with violating the Compulsory Education Law and fined $5 in the City Magistrates' Court. Weinberger appealed the case three times, but the decision was upheld.

did.unittitle: B-C, H-I, L-N, P, R-T, V-W (34)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters concerning United States vs. Emile Feltman , 1920. Feltman, an unregistered alien, was arrested in Arizona because of his activities in the International Workers of the World (I. W. W.) Weinberger, retained by the Workers' Defense Union, argued that deportation proceedings against Feltman should be cancelled due to his service in the Spanish American War. The plea was denied.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: See: Workers' Defense Union, box 21, folder 12

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, notes, and miscellaneous papers concerning the Feng Shun Exhibition Corporation, 1938-1941. Weinberger was attorney for this corporation organized to exhibit Chinese junks at the New York World's Fair and at The Golden Gate International Exhibition. The corporation failed to function and was dissolved.

scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters and legal papers concerning United States vs. Jose Ramon Fernandez, Rogelio Grecia, Pedro Martin, Jose Micezer, Elario Oretissa, Ramon Sanchez, Placido Santamaria , 1919. scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, notes, photographs, clippings, and miscellaneous papers concerning United States vs. Ricardo Flores Magon , 1918-1923. Weinberger attempted to obtain amnesty for Ricardo Flores Magon, who together with his brother Enrique Flores Magon and Librado Rivera, was convicted under the wartime Espionage Law for articles appearing in his periodical Regeneracion . Ricardo Flores Magon was not freed despite Weinberger's repeated insistance that his health was rapidly deteriorating in prison. He died in the United States Penitentiary in Leavenworth in 1920. Interest in this case was widespread throughout the United States and Mexico, due in large part to Weinberger's relentless letter writing. Among those interested in this case were Alice Stone Blackwell, Norman Hapgood, Alvaro Obregon, and Upton Sinclair.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, notes, clippings, and miscellaneous papers concerning New York vs. Harry Weinberger et al. , 1923-1925.

In January of 1923, Weinberger took over as manager of a production of Shalom Asch's The God of Vengeance . The play had been performed in German and Yiddish in New York for the past ten years without interference. In March 1923, however, Weinberger and the entire cast were charged with presenting an "obscene, indecent, immoral or impure drama, play, exhibition, show, or entertainment which would tend to the corruption of the morals of youth or others." Weinberger acted as attorney for the accused. They were convicted, but the decision was ultimately reversed on appeal.

The material in this section relates both to Weinberger's defense on the obscenity charge and to his duties as manager of the play. Through industrious letter writing, Weinberger mobilized a great deal of publicity and support for The God of Vengeance from prominent theatrical, social and religious leaders. This section includes letters from Roger N. Baldwin, Zachariah Chafee, Frank Crane, Felix Frankfurter, John H. Holmes, Fannie Hurst, Percy MacKaye, Elmer Rice, Stephen S. Wise, and many others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, notes, clippings, and miscellaneous papers. Weinberger was a close friend and advisor of the noted anarchist and radical Goldman. He represented her in several court cases and in some business matters. Weinberger was also an advisor of Goldman's associate Alexander Berkman. Material relating to both Goldman and Berkman is filed in this section.

Weinberger's relationship with Goldman spanned more than twenty years. He defended her in 1916 against a charge of distributing literature relating to birth control. In 1917, Goldman and Berkman were indicted in the United States District Court of New York for interfering with the execution of the Selective Service Act. They acted as their own lawyers, with Weinberger as an advisor. Goldman was sentenced to two years in the United States Penitentiary at Jefferson City, Missouri, and Berkman was sentenced to two years in the United States Penitentiary at Atlanta, Georgia. Charging no fee, Weinberger appealed to the United States Supreme Court on the basis that the draft law violated the thirteenth amendment. The Supreme Court declared the draft law constitutional and affirmed the convictions of Goldman and Berkman. They began their prison terms in 1918.

Weinberger corresponded with Goldman at great length while she was serving her term in the Jefferson City Prison. These letters touch on many subjects including Goldman's situation and the cases of other radicals in America. She also wrote about prison conditions and her friendship with fellow prisoner Kate Richards O'Hare.

Upon their release from prison, Goldman and Berkman, both professed anarchists, were held for deportation. Weinberger unsuccessfully tried to prove that Goldman was a citizen due to her marriage to Jacob A. Kersner. Goldman and Berkman were deported to Russia in December, 1919 on the S.S. Buford . They later fled to Latvia and then to Germany.

While Goldman was in exile in Germany, Weinberger attempted to straighten out a series of mishaps that had befallen her manuscript, "My Two Years in Russia." This manuscript was eventually published as My Disillusionment in Russia and My Further Disillusionment in Russia . There is extensive correspondence with Goldman, Clinton T. Brainard, and Doubleday, Page and Company in regard to these books.

Though widely separated by her deportation, Weinberger kept in fairly close touch with Goldman. She continued to write him, informing him of her travels and her activities in the Spanish Civil War shortly before her death.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The material in this section, after the correspondence, is broken into several sections as follows:

A) Emma Goldman: This section contains legal papers relating to Goldman's book, published as My Disillusionment in Russia and My Further Disillusionment in Russia . Also filed in this section are newspaper clippings on Berkman and Goldman and copies of the newspaper serialization of My Disillusionment in Russia .
B) Alexander Berkman: Copies of the magazine The Blast , published and edited by Berkman are filed in this section.
C) New York vs. Emma Goldman : This section contains material relating to Goldman's 1916 trial for distributing birth control information.

D) United States vs. Emma Goldman and Alexander Berkman : Material relating to Goldman and Berkman's 1917 trial for interfering with the execution of the Selective Service Act is filed in this section. This includes a two volume set of the stenographer's minutes of the court proceedings. Also contained in this section are documents concerning Weinberger's attempts to prove that Goldman was a United States citizen.

E) A. Berkman vs. The New York Produce Exchange Bank and E. Goldman vs. The New York Produce Exchange Bank : Legal papers concerning the above cases are contained in this section. Weinberger charged that the bank had no right to turn over Goldman and Berkman's funds to the United States Marshall.

F) California vs. Alexander Berkman : This section contains material concerning the extradition of Alexander Berkman to California where he was charged with first degree murder in connection with the Tom Mooney case. Proceedings were dropped by the district attorney in San Francisco because the United States Attorney desired to retain Berkman until the case of the United States vs. Emma Goldman and Alexander Berkman had been decided.

Weinberger was attorney for Kramer in these two cases. In the first case, Kramer was charged with interfering with the draft and sentenced to two years in the Atlanta Penitentiary. Kramer was charged in the second case with refusal to register under the Selective Service Act. scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, notes, pamphlets, and miscellaneous papers. Weinberger did not act as an attorney for Tom Mooney, the labor organizer convicted and imprisoned for the San Francisco Preparedness Day bombing in 1916, but he did try to help secure a pardon for Mooney from the Governor of California. Weinberger was able to obtain a letter from one of the jurors in the Mooney trial requesting that Mooney be pardoned. One of Weinberger's clients, Alexander Berkman, was involved in the case. The San Francisco authorities tried to associate him with the Mooney case by charging him with murder. They failed in their attempt to extradite Berkman to California.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Weinberger, whose interest in the theatre extended beyond mere legal questions, was intimately involved with the Provincetown Players and their work. He was close to founder George Cram Cook and his wife Susan Glasspell, and also to Eugene O'Neill. Weinberger was legal advisor and one of the directors of the Experimental Theatre, an organization growing out of the Provincetown Players. Papers concerning this group as well as the Provincetown Players are filed in this section.

As attorney for the Provincetown Players, Weinberger was involved in two disputes of interest. One involved the payment of the Federal War Tax on tickets. Weinberger claimed that the tax was inapplicable because the Provincetown Players was a club and not a theatre.
Weinberger successfully used the same defense when the Provincetown Players were twice charged with violating the "Sabbath law" by presenting plays on Sunday.

In 1913 Jesus Maria Rangel, Charles Cline, Abraham Cisneros, Pedro Perales, Jesus Gonzales, and Leonardo Vasquez attempted to enter Mexico from Texas to take part in the revolution against Diaz. The six men were captured in a fight with Texas authorities in which a deputy sheriff was killed. They were convicted of conspiracy to murder and sentenced to the Texas State Penitentiary.

After these men had served their minimum sentences, Weinberger began to work for their release. He waged a vigorous letter-writing campaign to create a demand for their pardon. He gained support from prominent individuals and labor organizations in both the United States and Mexico. To support the request for pardons for Rangel and the others, Weinberger pointed out that they had been model prisoners and had served their minimum terms. He also claimed that there was a lack of evidence that the men had actually committed murder and that their convictions were due to anti-Mexican prejudice. In 1926, Texas Governor Miriam A. Ferguson granted full pardons to the six men.

Due to the efforts of Weinberger and others, interest in this case was widespread. Among those concerned with the release of Rangel and the others were William A. Black, Alice Stone Blackwell, Roberto Haberman, Mercer C. Johnston, Daniel Kiefer, and Alvaro Obregon.

Vincent St. John, Charles Ashleigh, Giovanni Baldazzi, Jack Law, and Manuel Rey were members of the International Workers of the World (I. W. W.). They were charged, along with a hundred other members of the International Workers of the World (I. W. W.) with conspiracy to obstruct or violate the Selective Service and Espionage Acts. Clarence Darrow was attorney for the defendants. They were convicted in the United States Court in Chicago. Weinberger was retained to represent Baldazzi by the General Italian Committee of Defense and the Union of Italian Workers. He was retained by the Workers' Defense Union to represent Ashleigh, Law, and St. John. He was retained by the Political Prisoners Defense and Relief Committee to represent Manuel Rey.

In January 1922, Weinberger and the Italian Royal Embassy obtained executive clemency for Baldazzi and he was deported to Italy in February. Ashleigh was deported to England in February 1922. Rey was deported to Spain in 1923. Law had been granted executive clemency in December 1921. Weinberger worked to obtain pardon for St. John until April 1922, when he was asked to withdraw from the case.

Weinberger represented Selwyn and Company and the American Play Company in a dispute with Hollywood Plays over the sale of the motion picture rights to Avery Hopwood's play Fair and Warmer . Weinberger obtained a judgment in favor of his clients in 1941.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters. Shimuni was held for deportation as an alien likely to become a public charge. He declared that he had been defrauded of $1600 by S. N. Hanna. Weinberger could not bring suit against Hanna because the action would have to take place in New Jersey.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, notes, and miscellaneous papers. Simpson, a member of the Society to Lower Rents and Reduce Taxes on Homes, was fined for distributing handbills on a public street. Weinberger obtained a reversal of the decision by arguing that the ordinance under which Simpson was fined concerned distribution of advertising material, while Simpson was distributing petitions.

He was refused admission on the grounds that he was a stowaway without a passport, suffering from a dangerous disease, a convicted criminal, and likely to become a public charge.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, notes, clippings, and miscellaneous papers concerning Hugh Stange vs. Samuel J. Washansky , 1934-1936. Washansky wrote letters to various motion picture companies and producers charging that Stange's play False Dreams Farewell was a direct infringement of Washansky's play Fastest Thing Afloat . Stange brought suit charging that Washansky was blocking sale of the motion picture rights of his play. The plays were finally submitted to a committee of arbitration that decided that both were based on events in the public domain. Stange's play was then bought by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Pictures.

scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters and miscellaneous papers. Weinberger was legal advisor for the Theatre Alliance Inc., a cooperative group of actors, directors, stage hands, technicians, and administrators.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, notes, and miscellaneous paper concerning Herbert A. Thorpe vs. The Board of Education of the City of New York and New Jersey vs. Herbert A. Thorpe .

Thorpe, like Weinberger, did not believe in the propriety of compulsory vaccination. Weinberger defended Thorpe in two cases arising from this belief. In the first, Thorpe refused to allow his two children to be vaccinated, thereby preventing them from entering school. The Board of Education charged Thorpe with violating the compulsory education law and Thorpe sued the Board for $10,000 damages. Both cases were dismissed. In the second case, Thorpe was fined five dollars for distributing pamphlets in public streets. The charge was dismissed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, and notes concerning Harry Weinberger vs. Lillian Scott Troy , 1919-1921. Weinberger helped Troy gain admittance to the United States and acted for her in some business dealings concerning her motion picture theatre in England. Troy contested Weinberger's fee, and most of these papers concern his attempts to collect money he claimed was due him.

This section contains a speech Weinberger made on the subject of "Medical Freedom" and copies of clippings, pamphlets, and magazines collected by Weinberger on this subject.

Voss was finally deported to Germany.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters and legal papers concerning Erwin and Rita Weinberger vs. Trebuchs Realty Company . Weinberger represented the Weinbergers in a suit against the owners of the Ritz Theatre. Mrs. Weinberger charged that the theatre's negligence caused her to fall and injure herself. The case was settled out of court.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, notes, and miscellaneous papers concerning New York vs. Gray Wu , 1919-1920. Wu, secretary of the Chinese United Association, a labor union, was arrested on a felonious assault charge along with Roy Chio, Woo Chow, and Lew Fat. The assault charge against all was dismissed due to lack of evidence. Wu was charged with having a gun and given an indeterminate sentence. Weinberger, attorney for the defendent, accused the Employers Association of a frame-up against Wu because of his labor activities.
